story.storykicker: The mystery behind the flesh destroying properties of saw-scaled viper venom has finally been solved by scientists from Mysore University.
story.storybody:
The mystery behind the flesh destroying properties of saw-scaled viper venom has finally been solved by scientists from Mysore University.

Bites from the snake, formally called Echis carinatus, result in widespread tissue death around the wound. While scientists had long assumed certain venom toxins were responsible, the exact mechanism was unknown.

Indian researchers have now discovered that the body's own defences play a central role. They found that webs of DNA released by white blood cells called neutrophils to ensnare invading microbes actually block nearby blood vessels trapping damaging venom at the wound and starving cells of oxygen.

But the researchers may have also discovered a way to counteract the damage. In experiments on mice, they discovered that injecting an enzyme that cuts through the DNA webs called DNase1 can prevent local tissue destruction.

"According to the World Health Organisation more than 4 lakh people are subjected to amputations due to snake bites every year. Echis species are considered the major contributor for this terrifying debilitation in Africa and in Asia," said study leader Dr Kempaiah Kemparaju, a professor in the department of biochemistry.
 
"All these years it was a challenge for toxicologists to understand the molecular mechanism of tissue destruction. That is why we have no treatment, but our study is now providing the lead."
 
In a paper in scientific journal Nature Communications, the researchers describe how they injected viper venom into two groups of mice - one with low-levels of neutrophils and another with normal levels.
